awd_titl_txt: Efficient  High Frequency Integral Equations and Iterative Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is distinguished by its great wealth of potential scientific applications and broad educational activities. Indeed, the numerical algorithms to be developed in the research activities are applicable to realistic configurations in physics, acoustic/electromagnetic, and other disciplines. The major theoretical and computational difficulties in these fields result from the presence of complicating factors such as complex geometries (including aircraft, satellites, radars, antennas, etc.), high-frequency scattering, amongst others. The obtained methods will provide the ability to simulate such systems accurately in order to be applied  to the design of engineering vehicles and devices, including military and non-military radar, remote sensing satellites, noise reduction, stealth technology, and many others that will be positively impacted by the results of this proposal. The solvers obtained will be made readily available to industrial scientists, which will contribute to maintaining their competitiveness in particular in the aerospace industry. The educational impact will be significant in several areas. Graduate and undergraduate students will be rigorously trained in both scientific computing and mathematical analysis in order to enable them to face future challenges in science and technology.  They will acquire the skills needed in state-of-the-art in applied numerical methods, and this will provide them great opportunities to join high technological industries and contribute in further advancing the U.S technology while having a successful career.

The investigator plans to develop efficient and accurate algorithms for acoustic/electromagnetic wave propagation problems in complex structures. The new proposed research activities will have a significant impact in enabling advances in numerical methods and mathematics, and will result in a new family of numerical algorithms with enhanced capabilities over those currently available. The investigator plans to develop a robust non-overlapping domain decomposition method for the Helmholtz equation based on the utilization of optimized transmission conditions on the artificial interfaces and appropriate use of the adaptive radiation condition technique. This also will allow the design of an effective algorithm coupling finite and boundary elements. In the case of the high frequency regime, the investigator proposes to (1) use asymptotic expansions of solutions of the Helmholtz equation, namely the normal derivative of the total field, to rigorously develop a O(1) high frequency integral equations solver, (2) analyze the stability and convergence of the resulting algorithms, and (3) suitably combine high performance computing with the new proposed methods to efficiently tackle real-life problems. Parallel computing and mathematical analysis will be used to help achieve these goals.

por.por_cntn:
The project includes the development of efficient and robust algorithms based on high-frequency integral equations and non-overlapping domain decomposition methods for wave propagation problems. The aim resides in using these algorithms to deal with a variety of engineering and industrial applications. These include, for instance, antenna design, stealth and noise management, tomography, electromagnetic compatibility, microwave engineering and optics fiber.


 We  have developed an effective Krylov subspace method that significantly accelerates the convergence of the iterative procedure for the multiple scattering configurations. We used a novel  identification procedure that is well adapted to the high frequency aspect of the scattering problem as it retains the phase information associated with the iterates and delivers highly accurate solutions in a small number of iterations. In addition, a preconditioner based upon Kirchhoff approximations and the stationary phase method was introduced to further accelerate the convergence.  We designed a  Galerkin boundary element method for  the case of multiple-scattering problemsin the exterior of a finite collection of  compact and strictly convex obstacles. These algorithms have the capability of delivering multiple scattering iterations with the utilization of almost frequency independent numbers of degrees of freedom.In the case of the Neumann boundary condition, we have developed and analyzed a new class of  high-frequency integral equations based on the asymptotic expansion of the corresponding solutions.  This strategy represents the first contribution that addressed this difficult problem and we believe that it  will initiate other innovative numerical methods for the Neumann case.  Another novelty underlying the obtained numerical method resides in the incorporation of an adequate number of terms in the asymptotic expansion in order to obtain  frequency independent numerical algorithms.


Other research activities concern the design  of domain decomposition methods based on Robin boundary transmission conditions.  A challenging problem in the development of these methods resides in the assignment of degrees of freedom at cross points which are points shared by more than two subdomains.  We have introduced a convergent approach to the treatment of cross points which consists  of taking a common value for the degrees of freedom located on the nodes at the junction of several subdomains.  We have shown that this technique is efficient for various choices of nonlocal  transmission conditions and that the obtained local problems are well-posed. These methods were successfully applied to the case of perfectly matched layers and the adaptive radiation condition techniques.   Some of the obtained algorithms aided the design of a new domain decomposition method  for the Stokes-Darcy system.


Two Ph. D students were trained  in this project, and successful  research activities have been conducted to train and expose undergraduate students on some basic numerical methods such as finite/boundary elements and domain decomposition methods.  The resulting non-overlapping domain decomposition for the Helmholtz and Maxwell?s equations have been applied to real-life problems, and the codes are available to scientists. Graduate courses related to Partial Differential Equations and Numerical Techniques, in the Mathematical Sciences Department, have been strengthened by adding some new findings from this proposal to the curriculum. A series of lectures from the obtained results were given by the PI to applied scientists and industrialists.
